content: The "Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2003" requires disclosure of financial relationships between brokers and mutual fund companies. The "Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2003" mandates brokers to disclose compensation received for transactions involving open-end mutual funds registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2003 requires brokers to disclose transaction details to customers promptly. The disclosures must not be exclusively in registration statements or prospectuses, and the Commission will establish rules within a year of the Act's enactment. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2003 mandates disclosure of brokerage commissions by open-end companies, with the Commission setting rules for the format of disclosures. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2003 requires open-end companies to disclose brokerage commissions for registration statements and other filings with the Commission. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2003 requires open-end companies to disclose brokerage commissions for registration statements and other filings with the Commission. SEC. 3. MUTUAL FUND GOVERNANCE. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to require independent fund boards to have 25 percent interested persons, with the chairman being an interested person of the registered company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to require independent fund boards to have directors without material business or familial relationships with the company or its service providers. Independent directors must take action without the need for a vote by the board of directors. The Investment Company Act of 1940 now mandates that independent fund boards establish a committee of non-interested directors to select nominees and set qualification standards for board elections. These standards must be disclosed in the company's registration statement. The Investment Company Act of 1940 has been amended to redefine the term "Interested Person" to include individuals who have served as officers, directors, or employees of investment advisers or principal underwriters within the last 10 fiscal years. The Investment Company Act of 1940 has been amended to include individuals who have served as officers, directors, or employees of entities that have provided significant services to registered investment companies within the last 5 fiscal years. Additionally, individuals who are part of a class deemed unlikely to be independent by the Commission are also considered "Interested Persons." The Investment Company Act of 1940 has been amended to include individuals with a material business relationship, close familial relationship, or other reasons determined by the Commission with investment companies. The number of individuals in a clause has been increased from two to 5, and any natural person who is a member is also considered an "Interested Person." The Investment Company Act of 1940 has been amended to include individuals with specific relationships with investment advisers or principal underwriters as "Interested Persons." This includes those with material business relationships or close familial relationships with affiliated persons of the investment adviser or principal underwriter. The Investment Company Act of 1940 has been amended to define "significant service provider" within 270 days of the Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2003. This definition will include the investment adviser and principal underwriter. The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct a study to determine if creating a Mutual Fund Oversight Board with inspection, examination, and enforcement authority over mutual fund boards of directors would serve the best interests of investors. The board would be funded by assessments against mutual fund assets, have members selected by the SEC, and have rulemaking authority. A report on this study is due within 1 year of the enactment of the Act. The Securities and Exchange Commission will submit a report on a study regarding the creation of a Mutual Fund Oversight Board to the Senate and House committees after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. PORTFOLIO MANAGER COMPENSATION. The Securities and Exchange Commission must establish rules within 270 days of the Act's enactment for registered investment companies to disclose how portfolio managers are compensated and their ownership interests in the company's securities. SEC. 5. FINANCIAL LITERACY AMONG MUTUAL FUND INVESTORS STUDY. The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct a study to identify the level of financial literacy among investors purchasing shares of open-end companies, the necessary information for sound financial decisions, methods to increase transparency in transactions, existing efforts to educate investors, and a strategy to improve investor behavior. The Securities and Exchange Commission will submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Banking and Financial Services one year after enacting a study to improve investor behavior. SEC. 6. STUDY REGARDING MUTUAL FUND ADVERTISING. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on mutual fund advertising, including regulatory requirements, marketing practices, consumer impact, and recommendations for improving investor protections. A report on the study results must be submitted within 1 year of the enactment of the Act. The study results will be reported to the Senate's Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs and the House's Committee on Financial Services.
